results.title: Buildings and Bushfires-Improving the Chances of Survival
results.creator_credit: University of Melbourne and Television Production Unit
results.brief_description: Bushfires are an inevitable hazard in Australia. The tranquillity of the bush belies its potential to burn fiercely when conditions are suitable. This program shows how bushfires start fires in buildings, how embers, radiation and flame, aided by wind cause ignition and destruction of buildings; that embers are the most important means of ignition; that well-designed buildings have a very good chance of survival; and that such buildings will provide a safer place of refuge for people in bushfires.
results.title_for_label: Buildings and Bushfires-Improving the Chances of Survival
results.creator_credit_for_label: University of Melbourne and Television Production Unit

results.title: The Australian Alps: Mirka's Palace of Dreams
results.creator_credit: David Greig, David Morgan and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
This program is the last in a series of 6 documentaries that examine the wilderness areas of Australia.
Mirka Mora is an eccentric artist, French by birth, who had never before ventured into the wilderness nor slept in a tent. Along with Tim McCartney Snape, the first Australian ever to reach the summit of Mt. Everest, and a Nepalese Sherpa, she travels into the Kosciusko wilderness. Mirka’s unique and expressive personality helps viewers see and experience this wilderness from an artist’s perspective. A Teacher’s guide accompanies the video.
results.title_for_label: The Australian Alps: Mirka’s Palace of Dreams
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Greig, David Morgan and Kestrel Film Productions

results.title: Assault on the Land
results.creator_credit: Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rob Gell’s environment series”.
Examines the problems of salinity, showing how it affects not only the farmers, but all of us. Several methods currently in use to combat the problems are examined in areas of Victoria.

results.title: The Devil's toy
results.creator_credit: Claude Jutra, Marcel Martin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The skateboard gave the youngsters, who mastered its technique, a thrilling sensation of speed unexcelled by any other pavement sport. Filmed in 1966 on Montreal streets before the elongated rollerskate was banned, this film captures the exuberance of boys and girls having the time of their lives in free-wheeling downhill locomotion. Music by Pierre Brault. Sung by Genevieve Bujold.

results.title: Are girls calculating?
results.creator_credit: Diane O'Connor and Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: This videotape can be used not only in the maths-science classroom to encourage girls to see the importance of maths, but also as a valuable resource for careers teachers, and for social science units on either the workforce or sexism in society.

results.title: Advance Australia
results.creator_credit: Dept of the Interior and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: An interpretation of the Australian way of life, set against a background showing phases of Australia’s land, cities, natural resources, primary and secondary industries, arts, sports, recreations, and potentialities. Suitable for secondary school level.

results.title: C.E.P. What's that Got to Do with Being Here?
results.brief_description: The C.E.P. (Country Education Project) is an innovative body designed to tackle the industrial needs of rural communities. The projects are either school or community based, depending on individual educational requirements, and have a full-time regional co-ordinator. Outlines the C.E.P. philosophy and takes a close look at programs currently operating in the Ovens and King Valley regions of Victoria.

results.title: Down River
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Gippsland”.
For some, floods are a disaster, for others a necessary lifegiving event. The quite different ecology of the riverland is explored in this Gippsland Victoria series, which gives an insight into the Gippsland region and the full scope of natural phenomenon

results.title: The Children's Programme
results.brief_description:
In 1978 disadvantaged primary schools in the Northern Metropolitan area of Melbourne received supplementary grants programme which provided funding with the aim to enable greater equality of opportunity and develop closer ties with parents and the community. Featured is Lyndall Hall, a sub-school of Brunswick East High School and a camp held at Halls Gap. The Northern Metropolitan area covers the muncipalities of Coburg, Preston, Northcote, Heidelberg, Broadmeadows, Whittlesea and Eltham. 79 schools in this region are classiified as disadvantaged. Includes interview with Phillip Chislett from Northcote High Scool, Jan Andrews, Jan Cleeland and Bruce Westerman from Camp Meadows Primary School.

There are some sound issues.
